APPLICATION CHNJC 60084 S1872-2067(24)60084-7 10.1016/S1872-2067(24)60084-7 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 (a) The top and side views of geometric structures of the α-In2Se3 monolayer with downward and upward polarization, respectively. Purple and green denote the In atom and Se atom, respectively. The red cycles, blue cycles, and black arrows represent selected TM anchored sites, different Se atoms, and polarization directions, respectively. (b) The partial density of states of the α-In2Se3 monolayer with spin up state. (c) The average potential energy for In2Se3 monolayer along the perpendicular direction. The black arrow represents the direction of the intrinsic electric field. (d) The partial density of states and labelled p band centers of V@↓-In2Se3 and V@↑-In2Se3. Fig. 2 Dimensionality reduction for the binding energy of the TM@ In2Se3 using multidimensional scaling (a) and spectral embedding algorithms (b). Fig. 3 (a) Schematic of Distal, Alternating and Enzymatic Mechanisms for NRR. (b) Proposed screening strategy of NRR candidate catalysts. (c) N2 absorption free energies with end-on and side-on patterns. (d) The bonding schematic diagrams between N2 and TM. (e) The N-N bond length changes as a function of the excess electrons after N2 adsorption for TM@↑-In2Se3 and TM@↓-In2Se3 via the end-on configuration. Fig. 4 Free energy changes of *N2 + H+ + e– → *N2H (a) and *NH2 + H+ + e– → *NH3 (b) on TM@↑-In2Se3 with end-on configuration. Free energy changes of *N2 + H+ + e– → *N2H and *NH2 + H+ + e– → *NH3 on TM@↓-In2Se3 with end-on configuration (c) and on TM@↑-In2Se3 with side-on configuration (d). (e) The Gibbs free energy change of PDS for TM@In2Se3. (f) The limiting potentials for NRR and HER of TM@In2Se3 via Distal pathway, Alternating pathway, and Enzymatic pathway. Fig. 5 (a) The electrical conductivity of the V@In2Se3. (b) The calculated I-V curve for the V@In2Se3. Fig. 6 The Free energy diagrams during the NRR on V@↓-In2Se3 (a) and V@↑-In2Se3 (b) via distal pathway. Gibbs free energy diagram of the HER on V@↓-In2Se3 (c), V@↑-In2Se3 (d), Mo@↓-In2Se3 (e), Mo@↑-In2Se3 (f). Fig. 7 The partial density of states of V-3d on the V@↓-In2Se3 (a) and V@↑-In2Se3 (b). (c) Schematic diagram of TM-d orbitals splitting in the different crystal fields. The partial density of states of Mo-4d on the Mo@↓-In2Se3 (d) and Mo@↑-In2Se3 (e). (f) Schematic diagram of the crystal field effect between the dz 2 orbital of V atom and the ligand of Se atoms with the FE polarization switching. Fig. 8 (a) Schematics of N atomic orbitals and N2 molecular orbitals. (b) The partial density of states of free N2. The partial density of states and crystal orbital Hamilton populations of N2 on V@-In2Se3 (c) and V@-In2Se3 (d) via end-on configuration. The bonding and antibonding states are depicted by cyan and yellow, respectively. Fig. 9 (a) Interaction diagram between the 2p orbital of N atom and the d orbital of the TM atom with end-on configuration. (b) Important features from the Random Forest model for ΔG *NNH. Article Single-atom catalysts based on polarization switching of ferroelectric In2Se3 for N2 reduction Nan Mu a Tingting Bo a Yugao Hu a Ruixin Xu a Yanyu Liu b * Wei Zhou a * a Department of Physics, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Low Dimensional Materials Physics and Preparing Technology, School of Science, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Department of Physics Tianjin Key Laboratory of Low Dimensional Materials Physics and Preparing Technology School of Science Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Department of Physics, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Low Dimensional Materials Physics and Preparing Technology, School of Science, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China b College of Physics and Materials Science, Tianjin Normal University, Tianjin 300387, China College of Physics and Materials Science Tianjin Normal University Tianjin 300387 China College of Physics and Materials Science, Tianjin Normal University, Tianjin 300387, China * Corresponding author. The polarization switching plays a crucial role in controlling the final products in the catalytic process. The effect of polarization orientation on nitrogen reduction was investigated by anchoring transition metal atoms to form active centers on ferroelectric material In2Se3. During the polarization switching process, the difference in surface electrostatic potential leads to a redistribution of electronic states. This affects the interaction strength between the adsorbed small molecules and the catalyst substrate, thereby altering the reaction barrier. In addition, the surface states must be considered to prevent the adsorption of other small molecules (such as *O, *OH, and *H). Furthermore, the V@?-In2Se3 possesses excellent catalytic properties, high electrochemical and thermodynamic stability, which facilitates the catalytic process. Machine learning also helps us further explore the underlying mechanisms. The systematic investigation provides novel insights into the design and application of two-dimensional switchable ferroelectric catalysts for various chemical processes. Graphical Abstract An investigation of the effect of polarization switching on catalytic performance and intrinsic mechanisms is presented. Keywords In2Se3 monolayer Density functional theory Ferroelectric switching Single atom catalysts Nitrogen reduction reaction Machine learning 1 Introduction The rapid industrial development increases the urgent demand for Ammonia (NH3) due to its wide application as a reactant in the production of chemicals, fertilizers, and so forth [1–3]. However, current industrial N2 fixation relies mainly on the conventional Haber-Bosch process, which requires harsh conditions (500 °C and 300 atm) and not only consumes energy but also emits excessive greenhouse gases [4–6]. Therefore, the search for a green ammonia synthesis technology to mitigate energy and environmental challenges is imminent. Inspired by nitrogenases, electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), which combines N2 and H2O into NH3 in aqueous solution, has been receiving continuous attention owing to low-consumption and non-pollution [7–10]. Notably, single-atom catalysts (SACs), with high atom utilization and selectivity, stand out as promising heterogeneous NRR catalysts [11,12]. Two-dimensional (2D) materials, characterized by large surface-to-volume ratios and rich active sites, are ideal platforms for SACs by atomically dispersing transition metal atoms (TMs) [13,14]. A range of SACs have been demonstrated as potential NRR catalysts, including Nb-graphene [15], B/g-C3N4 [16], Fe2/g-CN [17], single-boron catalysts [18], and so forth. These SACs exhibit excellent catalytic performance stemming from coordination environments and electronic configurations [19]. However, regulation of the atomic configuration and precise control of production remains a challenge in the field of catalysis [20]. A series of noncentrosymmetric materials, particularly ferroelectrics (FE), were synthesized which optimize the reaction process and products depending on the polar property and polarization electric field (PEF) [21–23]. Following this law, the screening and adjustment functions of ferroelectric polarization are recognized [24]. Remarkably, In2Se3 garnered significant attention as a noble ferroelectric material, which makes it feasible to provide switched surface properties and perform a controlled catalytic reaction at room temperature [25–27]. Li and co-workers utilized polarization switching of In2Se3 to achieve electrically controlled half-metallicity and change of magnetic axis in antiferromagnets [28]. Kou et al. [29] have anchored TMs on In2Se3 monolayer with polarization downwards and upwards (TM@↓-In2Se3 and TM@↑-In2Se3) as electrocatalysts exhibit excellent stability and catalytic performance in CO2 reduction reaction. Most importantly, previous researchers [30–33] found a novel characteristic that metallicity and ferroelectricity can coexist, including Bi5Ti5O17, SrRuO3, In2Se3, LiOsO3 and so on. Li and colleagues [34] synthesized Co-doped and K-filled SBN as electrocatalysts and demonstrated ferroelectric polarization can promote surface adsorption and band-tilting favorable for electron transfer. Inspired by the above studies, we wondered whether controllable NRR activity might be achieved by switchable ferroelectric polarization based on TM@In2Se3. In this work, we systematically studied the NRR performance of TM@In2Se3 and further discussed the relationship among polarization orientation, surface characteristics, and catalytic activity. The results show that the catalytic process and reaction products can be controlled and selected by reversing the polarization. Meanwhile, the d-band center is proposed as a valid descriptor with the assistance of the Random Forest Algorithm (RFA). The significance of the present work is to demonstrate that ferroelectric switching SACs can alter and modulate both NRR and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activities leading to bifunctional catalysis. 2 Computational model and details Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) was carried out using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Emzerhof (PBE) exchange correlation functional via the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). The ion-electron interaction was described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method with a cut-off energy of 400 eV. The convergence criteria for energy and force were set to be 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV Å–1, respectively. The van der Waals (vdW) correction was considered using empirical correction of Grimme's DFT-D2 scheme. An extra 18 Å vacuum was inserted along the z direction to hinder interactions between the adjacent cells introduced by periodic boundary conditions. In addition, the corresponding Brillouin zone was sampled by a gamma-centered 3 × 3 × 1 k-point mesh for structural optimizations. Charge transfer was quantitatively described by Bader charge analysis. VASPKIT was adopted to deal with the electronic structures. More details about the calculation of Gibbs free energy are given in the Supporting Information. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were performed by the NVT ensemble and Andersen thermostat. The Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method was applied to find the energy barrier of polarization switching. In addition, the current-voltage (I-V) curve was performed using the NANODCAL package for better evaluating the quantum transport properties, which applying non-equilibrium Green's function density functional theory (NEGF-DFT) and simulating the nonlinear and non-equilibrium quantum transport processes. Finally, the PW-mat was used to measure the electrical conductivity based on Kubo-Greenwood (KG) formula [35]. Machine learning (ML) powers data classification and mechanism exploration. The input data array was preprocessed using multidimensional scaling (MDS) and spectral embedding as two dimensionality reduction algorithms. K-Means was chosen as the clustering algorithm and Random Forests (RF) were used for feature significance judgments. All methods are implemented using the Scikit-learning library. Additionally, the Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator (SISSO) was used to find relevant descriptors. The corresponding parameter are listed in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and electronic property of the In2Se3 monolayer The α-In2Se3 monolayer has quintuple layers stacked in the sequence of Se-In-Se-In-Se as shown in Fig. 1(a) . The optimized lattice parameter of the In2Se3 monolayer is a = b = 3.99 Å, which is in good agreement with previous studies [36]. For In2Se3, the asymmetric arrangement of Sec (central Se atom) induced by an external stimulus (e.g., the electric field) makes the polarization locked (down and up polarization states), while the position of Set atom (on the top surface) is maintained during polarization switching. The calculated energy barrier of polarization switching is 0.066 eV UC–1 as shown in Fig. S1. This change in structure caused a difference in electronic structure. The partial density of states (PDOS) in Fig. 1(b) shows that polarization switching significantly modifies the PDOS. Note that the spin effect is taken accounting into the calculation while only the spin-up state was shown due to the non-magnetic system. Interestingly, the electron occupancy distribution of Set depends on the polarization direction. For instance, the p-states of Set are close to the fermi level on ↓-In2Se3, while far away from the fermi level with deeper energy on ↑-In2Se3. This result indicates a difference in chemical activity between the two surfaces. As shown in Fig. 1(c), the asymmetric structure along the out-of-plane direction produces an electrostatic potential difference of 1.22 eV and a built-in electric field. Regrettably, Fig. S2 shows that the pristine In2Se3 itself is not suitable as an NRR catalyst, which is difficult to bind and cleave the strong N≡N triple bond under mild conditions. The N2 remains physisorption in both downward and upward polarizations. The bond length of N2 is not elongated compared to the free N2 in Table S2. In general, due to the co-existence of empty and occupied d-orbitals, TMs are usually introduced as active sites which can accept lone-pair electrons from nitrogen as well as donate the electrons backward to antibonding orbitals for weakening the N≡N bond [37,38]. Therefore, 29 kinds of TM are induced to the In2Se3 monolayer to improve the NRR performance as shown in Fig. S3. 3.2 Screening of ferroelectric SACs In general, doping and anchoring are two important methods to adjust catalytic performance. However, compared to the strategy of anchoring the transition metal, doping systems make nitrogen adsorb hardly as shown in Table S3. In addition, doping has been also proven more difficult to achieve for the In2Se3 than the anchoring method with a lower dynamic barrier [29]. Therefore, we chose to anchor a single transition metal atom on a 2 × 2 FE-In2Se3 substrate and investigated their electronic and catalytic properties. As shown in Fig. 1(d) and Table S4, the p are –1.698, –3.010, –2.942, and –3.140 eV for ↓-In2Se3, ↑-In2Se3, V@↓-In2Se3, V@↑-In2Se3, respectively (Energy band centers closer to the Fermi energy level are chosen for the magnetic system). The entire downward shift of the p-state is observed on TM@In2Se3 compared to pristine In2Se3 due to the charge injection of transition metal atoms into the substrate, which is consistent with previous research [39]. Moreover, it can be found the V atom shows different spin state in the upward and downward polarization directions. This difference in the electronic states greatly influences the catalytic process, which will be discussed in the following section. To be a qualified NRR catalyst, TM@In2Se3 should satisfy these criteria: excellent stability, high NRR activity, and good selectivity against HER [40]. After a strict screening process, a series of NRR catalysts with excellent performance were selected. 3.2.1 Stability of ferroelectric SACs For the TM@In2Se3 systems, the thermodynamic stabilities were evaluated through the binging energy E b-TM and summarized in Table S5. In general, the negative E b-TM ensures the stability of systems. There are three high-symmetrical sites on -In2Se3 labeled as S (Se atom top), C (vacancy top), and I (In atom top) in Fig. 1(a). As shown in Fig. S4, the most stable one is the top of the In atom (site I). The more negative E b indicates that the reaction process is exothermic, TM@In2Se3 is easy to synthesize, and there are strong interactions between TM and In2Se3 [41]. In addition, multiple factors related to transition metal influence the binding energy, such as atomic radius and number of electrons. These effects and trends of transition metal atoms were evaluated using artificial intelligence (AI) clustering methods. As a process of machine learning, AI clustering helps to organize data into subgroups with similar properties or elements through advancing geospatial intelligence, which is particularly effective in unsupervised learning and used in multiple domains such as human resources, data analytics, recommender systems, and social sciences. As shown in Fig. 2 , seven intrinsic features (Pauling electronegativity, ionic potential, electronic affinity, number of d-electrons, atomic radius, coordination number, and cohesive energy) of transition metal atoms determine their distribution in the two-dimensional plane after dimensionality reduction by the spectral embedding and multidimensional scaling (MDS) algorithms. The color of the point represents the binding energy. Compared to the spectral embedding algorithm, MDS provides a more dispersed and rational distribution. Using K-means, these transition metal atoms were classified into nine groups based on the two-dimensional coordinates obtained from MDS. The distances of transition metals in the 2D plane characterize their actual distances in a seven-feature-based vector multidimensional space, indicating the proximity of the metal atomic properties, i.e., the proximity of the combined assessment of seven factors, including electronegativity and atomic radius. These factors can influence the energies of individual metal atoms and coordination systems with Se atoms, and thus the binding energy shown in equation S1. This can also explain why close atoms have similar binding energies. In subsequent calculations, we also verified that systems of similar transition metals not only have similar binding energies but also exhibit similar catalytic performance. Therefore, this also provides guides on the screening steps of catalytic calculations and experimental synthesis. 3.2.2 NRR activity of ferroelectric SACs For the NRR process, there are four reaction paths to convert N2 to NH3 as shown in Fig. 3(a) , including distal, alternating, enzymatic, and consecutive patterns. Fig. 3(b) presents the screening strategy: Firstly, N2 should be effectively activated with a chemisorption (ΔG *N2 < 0 eV). Secondly, as the most possible potential determining step (PDS), the first and last hydrogenation step should be as small as possible (ΔG *N2–*NNH and ΔG *NH2–*NH3 < 0.98 eV). 0.98 eV is the Gibbs free energy change of the potential-determining step (ΔG PDS) of Ru (0001), which has been experimentally proven to own excellent NRR activity [42]. Finally, to guarantee the high NRR selectivity, ΔG *N2 < ΔG *H should be satisfied [43]. It is well known that N2 adsorption and activation is a key step. The N2 absorption free energies are calculated and presented in Fig. 3(c). In this case, the negative adsorption free energy (the pink area) represents that nitrogen can be adsorbed spontaneously, while the positive adsorption free energy (the green area) shows that nitrogen is hard to adsorb on surfaces. The yellow part, on the other hand, represents the inability of nitrogen to be activated in the system or the occurrence of the nitrogen adsorption configuration shift from side-on to end-on. The result indicates that most TM@In2Se3 prefer to absorb N2 with the end-on pattern. Meanwhile, the significant difference in the absorption free energies can be found in opposite polarization directions, demonstrating that introducing ferroelectric In2Se3 can effectively regulate the adsorption strength of N2. The ferroelectric substrate offers an additional degree for tuning the electronic structure of the TM atom by switching polarization directions. According to the first step of our three-step screening principle, structures with a free energy of nitrogen adsorption greater than 0 (green region) or with a transition in adsorption configuration (yellow region) will be discarded. As the reaction site, the TM atom can effectively activate the NN bond due to the presence of filled and unfilled d orbital, which is called the back-donation mechanism as shown in Fig. 3(d). As shown in Figs. S5–S7, Bader charge analysis demonstrates that the TM atom on ↑-In2Se3 tends to lose fewer electrons compared to ↓-In2Se3 after anchoring on the In2Se3, due to the built-in electric field caused by the difference in surface electrostatic potential. This implies that TM@↑-In2Se3 can better at the donation process in the “back-donation” mechanism and provide N2 more electrons, that is, more electrons were injected into N2-π* orbitals from the TM-d orbitals to activate N2, subsequently leading to higher NRR performance [40]. This is verified in Fig. 3(e) and Figs. S8–S9, where the more electron transfer, the longer bond length. The systems that can successfully activate nitrogen and keep the adsorption configuration unchanged are reserved for subsequent calculations of the protonation process. Fig. 4(a) shows free energy changes of the first hydrogenation processes with the end-on pattern for TM@↑-In2Se3, which is benchmarked to the Ru (0001). The Fe@↑-In2Se3, Co@↑-In2Se3, Ni@↑-In2Se3, etc. were excluded and not included in the subsequent screening process due to the first-step hydrogenation energy being greater than the screening criterion of 0.98 eV, which does not qualify as excellent catalyst candidates. The Sc@↑-In2Se3, Ti@↑-In2Se3, etc. were further considered about the last step of protonation energy as shown in Fig. 4(b). Consistent with previous findings, the TM@In2Se3 (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, and Pt) owns more positive adsorption free energy. Especially, TM atoms located at the front (e.g., Sc, Y, and Hf whose d orbital owns lesser electrons) or end of each period (e.g., Cu, Pd, and Pt whose d orbital is almost occupied completely) tend to have higher adsorption free energy, which is related to the availability of unoccupied and occupied d orbitals of the transition metals. Likewise, Figs. 4(c) and (d) show free energy changes of the first and last hydrogenation procedures on TM@↓-In2Se3 with the end-on configuration and TM@↑-In2Se3 with the side-on configuration. Then, 12 kinds of TM (Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Nb, Mo, Tc, Hf, Ta, W and Re) are selected for other hydrogenation steps. Except for Hf, the limiting potentials of the remaining TM@In2Se3 are less than 0.98 eV. This also validates the reasonableness and effectiveness of our screening procedure. To further reveal the reaction mechanism, the free energy diagrams via distal pathway, alternating pathway, and enzymatic pathway for NRR on TM@In2Se3 are plotted in Figs. S10–S22. Most of the obstacles originate from the first step of the hydrogenation process. The corresponding limiting potential indicated that the distal pathway is more favorable for the reaction process, which is also consistent with previous research results [44]. Solvent effects also were implemented in the binding strength of the reaction intermediates and the catalyst active site by VASPsol building implicit solvation model as shown in Fig. S23 [45]. The difference between the calculated limiting potentials with and without solvent effects in the two polarization directions is very small [46]. Therefore, for simplicity, solvation effects have not been considered further in this work. Additionally, NH3 desorption is not a problematic barrier due to the desorption process (*NH3 → NH3) does not affect the limiting potential and *NH3 is easily attacked by a proton to form NH4 + in the strongly acidic solution as shown in Figs. S24 and S25. Thus, the energy required to release the final NH3 molecule is not to be discussed. In all pathways, the first hydrogenation step usually occurs as the potential-determining step. To evaluate the inherent activity of electrocatalysts, the limiting potential (U L) was calculated and shown in Fig. 4(e). The minimum values of UL are located in V family elements, i.e., V for the 3d metal (–0.56 V at the ↓-In2Se3), Nb for the 4d metal (–0.56 V at the ↑-In2Se3), Ta for the 5d metal (–0.50 V at the ↑-In2Se3), and W with the similar electronic structure (–0.50 V at the ↑-In2Se3), while the smallest values arise from the elements at the end of specific column. Nb and Ta belong to group 2 in Fig. 2(b). V and W in the area near the edge of the group 2 belong to group 3 and group 6, respectively. Verified that adjacent components have similar performance. This is consistent with the previous research because of the appropriate number of d electrons [47]. The H adsorption, as a key competitive and side reaction of the NRR process, not only consumes protons and electrons but also blocks active centers [48]. Thus, the selectivity of the catalysts for HER and NRR was examined and displayed in Fig. 4(f). Obviously, the downward polarization state is conducive to the competitive reaction between NRR and HER, as the TM atom transfers fewer electrons to the H atom. As the promising NRR catalysts, the V@↓-In2Se3, Mo@↓-In2Se3, and Fe@↑-In2Se3 exhibit the theoretical Faradaic efficiency (FE = 1/(1 + eδG/kBT ) × 100%) of up to 100%. The U L of V@↓-In2Se3 is 0.56 eV, which can be comparable to the current mainstream SACs listed in Table S10. Therefore, the V@↓-In2Se3, Mo@↓-In2Se3, and Fe@↑-In2Se3 are considered promising catalysts. Unlike the semiconducting properties of the pristine In2Se3 monolayer and the energy band gap of 0.86 eV, localized metallization is caused by hybridization between anchored TM atoms and surrounding Se atoms (Figs. S26–S28). Fig. 5(a) shows the electrical conductivity performance difference of the V@In2Se3 at different frequencies [49]. However, the density of states of distant neighbors demonstrates the retention of substrate semiconductor properties and ferroelectricity [29]. Benedek et al. [50] propose that there is no fundamental incompatibility between metallicity and polar distortions from the perspective of theoretical calculations. Fig. 5(b) shows the I-V curve of the transport devices based on V@In2Se3 at a bias voltage up to 2.0 V. Clearly visible, V@↓-In2Se3 own lower current compared to V@↑-In2Se3 under the same bias voltage. This is caused by V@↓-In2Se3 having a smoother energy band at the Fermi energy. In addition, whether polarization can effectively switch has been proven by the CI-NEB method due to the dependence of catalytic activity on it. After the surface is modified by V atoms, the energy barrier (0.26 eV UC–1) is improved compared with the pure In2Se3 as shown in Fig. S29, but the experimental realization of SAC polarization reversal is still feasible. 3.3 The origin of NRR activity for ferroelectric SACs It is worth mentioning that the direction of polarization has a significant effect on the catalytic activity. In addition to the nitrogen adsorption, the NRR reaction activity also exhibits remarkable differences on the ↓-In2Se3 and ↑-In2Se3 surfaces. For a more intuitive display, the free energy diagrams of those systems with excellent catalytic performance are shown in Fig. 6 . For the V@↓-In2Se3, the limiting potential occurs in the second hydrogenation process (*NNH → *NNH2) with 0.56 eV, while for the V@↑-In2Se3, the first step of the hydrogenation process (*NN → *NNH) is the reaction rate-determining step with 0.83 eV. This shows that polarization switching greatly affects the NRR process on the V@In2Se3 surface. For Mo@In2Se3, the limiting potentials are –0.69 and –0.64 V on the ↑-In2Se3 and ↓-In2Se3, respectively. Unlike V@In2Se3 and Mo@In2Se3, Fe@In2Se3 tends to participate in reactions with the side-on absorbed configuration as shown in Figs. 4(a) and (d). The N2 absorption free energies are 0.86 and –0.01 eV for the Fe@↓-In2Se3 and for the Fe@↑-In2Se3, respectively. The Fe@↓-In2Se3 does not effectively activate nitrogen and is excluded. The free energy changes of Fe@↑-In2Se3 with enzymatic and consecutive pathways are shown in Fig. S15. The limiting potential of both is determined by the first step of the hydrogenation process. Although two reaction pathways have the same limiting potential, the *N*NH2 owns lower energy compared to the *NH*NH. This implies that hydrogen ions are more likely to continue attacking a nitrogen atom until it becomes ammonia desorbed. The HER process was considered as the main competitive reaction of NRR as shown in Figs. 6 and S30. The corresponding hydrogen adsorption free energy is 0.85, 0.75, 0.84, 0.64, and 1.05 eV among V@↓-In2Se3, V@↑-In2Se3, Mo@↓-In2Se3, Mo@↑-In2Se3, and Fe@↑-In2Se3 respectively. This indicates that HER is difficult to occur in the ↓-In2Se3 compared to the ↑-In2Se3. The higher ΔG H* is beneficial for the NRR process. As a matter of convenience, the Gibbs free energy diagrams of the HER are shown in Figs. 6(c) and (f). The V@↑-In2Se3 and Mo@↑-In2Se3 were not considered candidates for NRR as they undergo spontaneous HER at applied electrode potential and are susceptible to *H poisoning on the surface. Furthermore, the PDOS was plotted to explore the mechanism of polarization-dependent catalytic activity. The isolated TM atom has five degenerate d orbitals, while the TM atom and three nearby Se atoms form triangular pyramid (C3 symmetry) in TM@In2Se3, which results the spin-polarized TM-d orbits split into A(d z 2)and E(d xy d yz d xz d x2–y2) under the influence of the crystal field as shown in Fig. 7(c) [51]. The distribution of state density is determined by the polarization direction. As shown in Fig. 7(f), the d z 2 orbital protrudes out of the plane. Thus, the H-s and N-2p states hybridize mainly with the A state and the spatial maximum overlap of their orbital wave functions determined the interaction, which is related to the energy level of A state. When the polarization direction is reversed up and down, the presence of electrostatic potential difference causes a consequent change in the relative energy levels of A, leading to a difference in the hybridization of A with H-s and N-2p in the up and down directions. In short, the polarization reversal causes the d electrons to rearrange and exhibit different spin states. Therefore, the HER and NRR activity changes with the flip of the polarization switching. Particularly, the difference of A state of Mo@In2Se3 is higher than that of V@In2Se3 and Fe@In2Se3. This is attributed to the difference in electronegativity between the elements V, Fe, and Mo. The greater the electronegativity, the stronger the response to the electrostatic potential difference. The E state appears to leftward shift and the A state shows a decreasing trend in ↑-In2Se3 compared to ↓-In2Se3, which is consistent with the polarization-dependent p states of Set in the Fig. 1(b). This is because the Set-p states of ↓-In2Se3 are closer to the Fermi level and interact strongly with the TM-d orbitals in the separated A and E states. In contrast, the Set-p state of ↑-In2Se3 is far away from the Fermi level and interacts weakly with the TM-d orbitals, leading to the degradation of the A and E states. As mentioned above, the transition from ↓-In2Se3 to ↑-In2Se3 leads to an upward shift of d z 2 orbital energy levels as shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S31. This relationship between vertical orbital energy and FE polarization direction can be ascribed to the crystal field effect. The Fig. 7(f) shows that the downward movement of Se atom as an electronegative ligand makes the d z 2 orbital energy level raised under the electrostatic interaction, which is consistent with the PDOS [52]. These results suggest that the polarization direction of the substrate affects the adsorption of small molecules by changing the electronic states of the TM atoms, which subsequently tunes the reaction activity. Therefore, the polarization-dependent electronic states of TM atoms indicate that TM@In2Se3 could be the potential bifunctional catalyst. To explore the underlying factors influencing NRR performance, the PDOS and projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) were also calculated and presented in Fig. 8 , in which the strong interaction between d orbital of V and p orbital of N was observed. Correspondingly, compared with the molecular orbitals of free N2 (Figs. 8(a) and (b)), N2 was activated through feedbacking electrons from the occupied d orbitals of TM to the 2π* orbitals of N2, making the partially occupied 2π* orbitals move towards the Fermi level. The strong d-2π* coupling effect not only activates N2 effectively but also promotes the subsequent hydrogenation. Thus, the proximity of the valence band contribution of the TM d-states to the Fermi energy is of central importance. More specifically, the energetic location of the d-state is worth considering. To quantify the location of the d-states of the TM atom, the d-band center can be introduced. Fig. 9(a) shows the interaction between TM-d and N-2p orbitals. The hybridized energy levels split into the occupied bonding orbitals below the E-Fermi and the unoccupied anti-bonding states above the E-Fermi. The bonding strength between the adsorbed small molecules and the catalyst substrate is influenced by the occupancy level of anti-bonding states, which is reflected in the motion of the d-band center relative to the Fermi energy level. Then, the Random Forest Algorithm (RFA) also verifies the importance of the d-electron, and the corresponding feature importance is shown in Fig. 9(b). The leave-one-out cross-validation (LOOCV) method was used to avoid overfitting. The mean importance of d-electrons, Radius, Electronegativity, and Affinity energy are 0.36, 0.11, 0.22, and 0.31, respectively. This is consistent with the results in Fig. 9(b). The standard deviation of d-electrons, Radius, Electronegativity, and Affinity energy are 0.05, 0.01, 0.04, and 0.04, respectively. Smaller standard deviations indicate the stability of feature importance. The results displayed in Fig. 9(c) give a direct linear relationship between the limiting potential and ε d. Unlike the conventional d-band center, which is inversely proportional to the energy, the limiting potential gradually increases as the d band center moves upward. This is consistent with the pattern found in the –4–0 eV energy level by Chen et al. and may be related to the spreading of the d band shape [53–55]. In addition to the ε d, there is a negative correlation between the limiting potential and excess electrons of N2 as shown in Fig. 9(d). This means the more N2 obtains excess electrons, the smaller U L values will be (N≡N bond is activated more efficiently). On the contrary, the fewer excess electrons lead to a subsequently more difficult hydrogenation process and higher limiting potential. Notably, the V@↓-In2Se3 is not considered for fitting due to its different rate determination step compared to other systems. In a broader sense, the establishment of a link between catalytic activity and electronic properties will have a far-reaching influence on energy conversion. Moreover, the Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator (SISSO) is also applied to creating a descriptor for NRR. A series of fundamental parameters inherent to anchored TM were selected as input features, including the Pauling electro-negativity of the metal atoms (χ), the d electron number (N), atomic radius (R), electron affinity energy (A) [56]. The best descriptor for U L is depicted as Eq. (S12) in the Supporting Information. As illustrated in Fig. 9(e), the SISSO predicted values and DFT results have a high R 2 of 0.99 and low root-mean-square error (RMSE). The mean absolute errors (MAEs) of SISSO given by LOOCV are relatively low with 0.12 eV, which indicates that the well-trained model can accurately predict the limiting potential. The electron localization function (ELF) was introduced to investigate the interaction between TM-centers and adsorption intermediates. Taking the V@↓-In2Se3 monolayer (the N2 molecule absorbed with the end-on configuration) as an example, the bonding features of V@↓-In2Se3 and N2 were used to analyze the N2 activation in detail. Fig. 10(a) shows the formation of the Ionic bond between the V atom and surrounding Se atoms. For free N2 molecules, the NN bond is inert covalent. Bonding with TM enhanced the polarity of N2 which makes the first hydrogenation facile as shown in Fig. 10(b). Subsequently, the last hydrogenation is also easier thanks to stronger ionic interactions between TM-N in the NH2 group as shown in Fig. 10(c). Moreover, the charge density difference (CDD) depicts the charges redistribution that accompanies polarization switching as shown in Fig. 11(a) . The pronounced charge accumulation and depletion both weaken the NN triple bond through reducing the electron density between nitrogen atoms. Correspondingly, the total magnetic moment is 1.68 and 1.75 μB of V@↓-In2Se3 and V@-In2Se3 as shown in Fig. S32, which is same as the Bader charge results. The increased spin state is ascribed to the surface potential difference introduced by the intrinsic polarization and rearrangement of d electrons as shown in Fig. S33, which influences the free energy in the HER and NRR process. The charge transfer is also examined along each hydrogenation step. The intermediates were divided into three moieties: the FE In2Se3 substrate (moiety 1), the single TM atom (moiety 2), and the adsorbed N x H y species (moiety 3) (Fig. 11(b)). The initial charge of each moiety is regarded as zero before N2 adsorption. Taking V@In2Se3 as an example, Figs. 11(c) and (d) shows the N2 molecule and the In2Se3 moiety obtain 0.20, 1.01 and 0.24, 0.91 e– from the V atom of ↓-In2Se3 and ↑-In2Se3, respectively. In the subsequent hydrogenation step, N x H y and In2Se3 still remain electron acceptors while V atom still donates electrons. Interestingly, single metal atom (moiety 3) shows a more pronounced pattern of electron donors and thus act as active sites for NRR. The corresponding bond length variations of V-N and NN are displayed in Fig. S34. The NRR performance is closely related to the adsorption strength of *N, and either too strong or too weak *N adsorption is detrimental to the catalytic activity. This correlation is also mentioned in other works which show that the *N can describe the states of other intermediates [57]. The TM atom acts as the electron donor and single active site and the N x H y serves as electron acceptor. The activity trend can be identified by seeking the scaling relationship of the N x H y species for different TM@In2Se3. Fig. S35 shows the free energy of *NNH and *NH2 is positively and negatively proportional to the adsorption energy of N* in, respectively. This feature offers a chance to refine a singular descriptor predicting the reaction activities. In addition to high catalytic activity, the possibility of unfavorable poisoning of O-containing species (e.g., O, OH, and H2O) on the catalyst surface should also be considered during NH3 synthesis [58]. Hence, the ΔG of O-containing species adsorbed on the V@In2Se3 was explored at different applied potentials and pH. The system is in equilibrium with the electrons, protons, and liquid water in the electrolyte through the following steps: TM@In2Se3 + nH2O ↔ TM@In2Se3/O x *H y * + (2x–y)(H+ + e–) where TM@In2Se3/O x *H y * denotes the TM@In2Se3 covered by *OH or *O. If the potential is below 0.59 V, there will be no adsorbate on the V@↓-In2Se3 surface as shown in Fig. 12(a) , which keeps the catalyst surface clean for subsequent nitrogen adsorption. The U L of NRR (–0.56 V) is more negative which proved that the V@↓-In2Se3 can adsorb NRR intermediates without hindrance under operating conditions. The adsorption free energy of *N2 and *H, as well as other possible intermediates, *OH and *O, were studied as a function of applying electrode potential. These intermediates (*H, *OH, and *O) with changeable free energy decided by the electrode due to accompanied by the interchange of electrons. On the contrary, N2 adsorption as a thermochemical step owns constant free energy and does not vary with potential. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the V site is overwhelmingly covered by N2 in the potential range from –0.87 to –0.37 V. Most importantly, the U L of V@-In2Se3 (–0.56 V) is within this potential window which ensures the good NRR selectivity. For V@↑In2Se3, the surface-active sites of the catalyst are covered by OH without external voltage as shown in Fig. 12(c). However, the applied potential needed by the NRR process ensures the N2 absorption due to the U L (–0.83 V) is within the potential window in Fig. 12(d). These results show that SACs can effectively inhibit the adsorption of small oxygen-containing molecules and clear the obstacles for subsequent NRR reactions. Finally, the electrochemical and thermodynamic stabilities of the V@↓-In2Se3 were further estimated. The Pourbaix diagram in Fig. 13(a) indicates that V@↓-In2Se3 can metal atoms can stably exist on the substrate surface instead of dissolving in solution in the form of ions under the corresponding pH and applied voltage. Meanwhile, the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation shows that all atoms oscillate around the equilibrium position and no structural collapse occurs at 300 K as shown in Fig. 13(b). 4 Conclusions In summary, this study focuses on the catalytic activity and selectivity of single-atom catalysts based on Ferroelectric In2Se3 for the NRR process. A series of SACs, capable of efficiently driving the N2 reduction with low energy cost and high faradaic efficiency, were selected as potential bifunctional catalysts. The V@↓-In2Se3 shows the best catalytic performance with a limiting potential of –0.56 V. Particularly, the research on the surface states proved the absolute advantage of nitrogen adsorption compared to other small molecules (*O, *OH, and *H). Finally, the VIMD and pourbaix diagram indicated that the V@↓-In2Se3 possesses high electrochemical and thermodynamic stabilities, which is beneficial for electrocatalysis. Our results demonstrate that polarization switching can control the catalytic activity and separate different polarization domains, which provides a way for further exploring more switchable ferroelectric electrocatalysts based on different chemical reactions. coredata.dc:description: The polarization switching plays a crucial role in controlling the final products in the catalytic process. The effect of polarization orientation on nitrogen reduction was investigated by anchoring transition metal atoms to form active centers on ferroelectric material In2Se3. During the polarization switching process, the difference in surface electrostatic potential leads to a redistribution of electronic states. This affects the interaction strength between the adsorbed small molecules and the catalyst substrate, thereby altering the reaction barrier. In addition, the surface states must be considered to prevent the adsorption of other small molecules (such as *O, *OH, and *H). Furthermore, the V@?-In2Se3 possesses excellent catalytic properties, high electrochemical and thermodynamic stability, which facilitates the catalytic process. Machine learning also helps us further explore the underlying mechanisms. The systematic investigation provides novel insights into the design and application of two-dimensional switchable ferroelectric catalysts for various chemical processes.
